results.title: Visages de femmes = Faces of women
results.creator_credit: Desire Ecare and Films de la Lagune
results.brief_description: Twelve years in the making, “Visages de Femmes” is a wonderfully unpredictable and creative look at the financial, sexual and emotional emancipation of African women. The film is a series of episodes linked by a chorus featuring traditional singing and dancing. Ecare’s achievement is to create a visual feast which owes little to colonial models of cinema.

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 5 & 6
results.creator_credit: Christopher Ralling, Michael Gill, Channel 4, Malone Gill Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: Precious but perishable Due to poor storage in wooden barrels in the middle ages, wine tended to deteriorate quickly. This led to England, the major consumer of the time, importing claret from Bordeaux which was close, and the stronger, longer lasting, malmsey and sack (sherry) from the eastern Mediterranean and Spain. “The slopes of gold” looks at the rise of the great vineyards of Burgundy where each tiny vineyard produces individual wine whose qualities are determined by the geology of the area.

results.title: Setting the scene: the Metropolis case
results.brief_description: A limited edition DVD presented exclusively to visitors of the ‘Setting the Scene’ exhibition at the Australian Centre of the Moving Image, Federation Square, Melbourne. featuring ‘The Metropolis case’ and special bonus material (‘The Restoration’ and ‘Photo Gallery’).

results.title: Zero [DVD] (D)
results.brief_description: This is the debut feature of surrealist avant-garde filmmaker James Fotopoulos. A work that oscillates between scenes of serenity and ones of utter depravity, “Zero” tells the story of a man (Matthew Buckley) sliding into absolute isolation, accompanied by pornography, mental illness and disease. In his drab apartment, with its exposed pipes and austere furnishings, the man has pasted explicit pornographic and medical images. He also has collected an array of jars that hold specimens of tumours and animals. The man seeks intimacy and release from his seclusion but his only source of contact is his extensive collection of pornographic magazines that he pours over and speaks to in an array of demonic monologues, whilst a gruesome cyst grows on his forearm. The man’s masturbatory fantasies lead to him romancing the armless upper half of a store mannequin whom he covets. In alternate sequences the man is witnessed strolling through fields and forests, having found a space (perhaps imaginary) in which to reside free from the conflict and poisonous, misogynist, racist ranting of his mind. Fotopoulos’ experimental, minimalist cinema despondently explores the spaces of physical desire and the dark parameters of loneliness. The industrial sound-scape, that marks all of this Midwestern filmmaker’s work, adds to the sense of futility and misanthropy that permeates the unilateral narrative. Music by Tom Nicholl. Features images of pornography and excessive female nudity and medical experimentation. Warning: some scenes may disturb.

results.title: Setting the scene: landscape spaces (Chris Kennedy and Stephen Curtis)
results.brief_description: Interviews with Chris Kennedy and Stephen Curtis, Australian production designers on their work. Chris Kennedy talks about the two different approaches he took for two films, the building of a town in The Proposition and finding already existing locations for The Road. Stephen Curtis talks about his approach to production designing on his work on Bedevil and Night Cries. Prodcued by AFTRS and ACMI for ACMI’s Setting the Scene exhibition.

results.title: Zea
results.creator_credit: Andre Leduc, Jean-Jacques Leduc, Robert Forget and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A superb visual trick that will mystify its audience, this animated film transforms the commonplace into magic. The film presented a serious technical challenge because the subject was both elusive and explosive. A film to watch, enjoy and laugh about. (Awards: Cannes; Chicago; Elmhurst; Columbus; Paris; Genie, Toronto.) Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Tree that remembers (D)
results.creator_credit: Masoud Raouf and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In 1992 a young Iranian student and an ex-prisoner of war under the Ayatollah’s regime during the 80’s, hanged himself on the outskirts of a small town in Canada. Director Masoud Raouf, also an ex-prisoner under the Ayatollah regime has sought to address and understand the inherent long-term issues surrounding the survival of ex-political prisoners and asylum seekers, raising issues of cultural integration and disparity between Western cultures and refugees generally whilst giving air to subjects usually silent within Western communities. A group of former prisoners in Iran elucidate on their personal experiences describing the horrors of torture and imprisonment and the means in which they survived spiritually throughout their detainment. “Boxing” a form of solitary confinement is described in detail with its psychological effect - a form of torture that mimics the corpse in order to break the spirit.

results.title: The Town mouse and the country mouse
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart, Kathleen Shannon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Evelyn Lambert’s well-known style of animation using paper figures and brightly coloured backgrounds, based on an Aesop fable. Tells the simple story of two mice with different lifestyles and suggests that it is far better to live simply and in peace than live in luxury amidst danger

results.title: Vision in mathematics: motion geometry
results.brief_description: Reviews and illustrates three isometric plane transformations (translation, reflection, rotation). Examines some combinations of these operations and includes tables to show the final results.
